Path filtering

From libfswatch documentation https://emcrisostomo.github.io/fswatch/doc/1.14.0/libfswatch.html/path-filtering.html

A filter type (fsw_filter_type) determines whether the filter regular expression is used to include and exclude paths from the list of the events processed by the library. libfswatch processes filters this way:

  • If a path matches an including filter, the path is accepted no matter any other filter.
  • If a path matches an excluding filter, the path is rejected.
  • If a path matches no lters, the path is accepted.

Said another way:

  • All paths are accepted by default, unless an exclusion filter says otherwise.
  • Inclusion filters may override any other exclusion filter.
  • The order in the filter definition has no effect.

To simplify creation of regular expressions (especially considering two different flavors can be specified, each one different from pcre that nim uses) it is recommended to use rx helper

Imports

../other/oswrap, ../other/rx, ../core/all, wraphelp

Types

FsMonitor = object
  handle*: FswHandle
  Source   Edit 
FswEvent = object
  path*: cstring             ## where the event was triggered.
  time_t*: cint              ## Unix timestamp for time when the event was triggered.
  flags*: ptr FswEventFlag   ## array of fsw_event_flag of size flags_num.
  flags_num*: cuint          ## size of the flags array.
  Source   Edit 
FswEventFlag = enum
  fefNoOp = 0,              ## No event has occurred
  fefPlatformSpecific = 1,  ## Platform-specific placeholder for event
                             ## type that cannot currently be mapped
  fefCreated = 2,           ## An object was created
  fefUpdated = 4,           ## An object was updated
  fefRemoved = 8,           ## An object was removed
  fefRenamed = 16,          ## An object was renamed
  fefOwnerModified = 32,    ## The owner of an object was modified
  fefAttributeModified = 64, ## The attributes of an object were modified
  fefMovedFrom = 128,       ## An object was moved from this location
  fefMovedTo = 256,         ## An object was moved to this location
  fefIsFile = 512,          ## The object is a file
  fefIsDir = 1024,          ## The object is a directory
  fefIsSymLink = 2048,      ## The object is a symbolic link
  fefLink = 4096,           ## The link count of an object has changed
  fefOverflow = 8192         ## The event queue has overflowed.
  Source   Edit 
FswEventTypeFilter = object
  flag*: FswEventFlag
  Source   Edit 
FswFilterType = enum
  filterInclude = 0, filterExclude = 1
  Source   Edit 
FswFsMonitorFilter = object
  text*: cstring
  filterType*: FswFilterType
  caseSensitive*: bool
  extended*: bool
  Source   Edit

proc addFilter(handle: FswHandle; filter: FswFsMonitorFilter): cint {.
    importc: "fsw_add_filter", ...raises: [], tags: [].}
Adds a filter to the current session. A filter is a regular expression that, depending on whether the filter type is exclusion or not, must or must not be matched for an event path for the event to be accepted.   Source   Edit

Determines whether the monitor recursively scans each watched path or not. Recursive scanning is an optional feature which could not be implemented by all the monitors. By default, recursive scanning is disabled.   Source   Edit
